problem:
How many integers are common solutions to these three inequalities? \[
\begin{array}{cccc}
(1) & -3y & \geq & y+7 \\
(2) & -2y & \leq & 12 \\
(3) & -4y & \geq & 2y+17
\end{array}
\]
model_solution:
Step 1: Rearrange inequality (1) to isolate y on the left side.
\[
\begin{array}{r}
-3y \ge y+7 \\
\hline
-4y \ge 7
\end{array}
\]
Step 2: Solve the inequality for y by dividing each side by -4, remembering to reverse the direction of the inequality.
\[
\begin{array}{r}
-4y\ge 7 \\
\hline
y\le -\frac{7}{4}
\end{array}
Step 3:
\[
\begin{array}{r}
-2y \le 12 \\
\hline
y \ge -6
\end{array}
\]
Step 4: Rearrange inequality (3) to isolate y on the left side.
\[
\begin{array}{r}
-4y \ge 2y+17 \\
\hline
-6y \ge 17
\end{array}
\]
Step 5: 
\[
\begin{array}{r}
-6y \ge 17 \\
\hline
y \le -\frac{17}{6}
\end{array}
\]
Step 6: 
\[
\begin{array}{r}
y \le -\frac{17}{6} \\
y \ge -6 \\
y \le -\frac{7}{4}
\end{array}
\]
The common solution set for all three inequalities is $-6 \le y \le -\frac{17}{6}$.
Step 7: Count the integers in the interval $-6 \le y \le -\frac{17}{6}$, which is the same as $-6 \le y < -3$ since $y$ cannot equal $-\frac{17}{6}$.
Step 8: There are 4 integers in the interval $-6 \le y < -3$, namely $-6, -5, -4,$ and $-3$.
Step 9: There are 4 integers in the interval $-6 \le y < -3$, namely $-6, -5, -4,$ and $-3$.
Step 10: There are 4 integers in the interval $-6 \le y < -3$, namely $-6, -5, -4,$ and $-3$.
